column9: Holi - A festival of colors, marking the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil.

column17: Sports Day - A day dedicated to sports and physical activities where students participate in various sports competitions.
column21: Quarterly Exams: Quarterly exams are conducted after the completion of one-fourth of the academic year. They cover the syllabus taught in the first quarter of the academic year.

column9: Good Friday - A day of mourning for Christians, commemorating the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.
column13: Children's Day - Celebrated on 14th November every year to honor the memory of India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, who was fondly called 'Chacha Nehru' (Uncle Nehru) by children.
column17: Science Exhibition - An event that showcases the scientific talent of the students. They display their scientific models, projects, and experiments.
column21: Unit Tests: Unit tests are conducted after the completion of a unit or a chapter in the syllabus. They are usually conducted to assess the understanding of the students in a particular topic.

column9: New Year's Day - A day to celebrate the beginning of a new year.
column13: Independence Day - Celebrated on 15th August every year to commemorate India's independence from British colonial rule in 1947.
column17: Annual Day - A day of celebration for the school's achievements throughout the year. Students showcase their talents through various cultural programs.
column21: Annual Exams: Annual exams are the most important exams in a student's academic year. They usually cover the entire syllabus of the academic year and are conducted once a year.

column9: Republic Day - A day to commemorate the adoption of the Indian constitution and the establishment of the Republic of India.
column13: Republic Day - Celebrated on 26th January every year to commemorate the adoption of the Indian Constitution on this day in 1950.
column17: Sports Day - A day dedicated to sports and physical activities where students participate in various sports competitions.
column21: Half-Yearly Exams: Half-yearly exams are conducted after the completion of half of the academic year. They cover the syllabus taught in the first half of the academic year.

column9: Holi - A festival of colors, marking the arrival of spring and the victory of good over evil.
column13: Gandhi Jayanti - Celebrated on 2nd October every year to mark the birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, the father of the Indian nation and a champion of non-violence.

column21: Quarterly Exams: Quarterly exams are conducted after the completion of one-fourth of the academic year. They cover the syllabus taught in the first quarter of the academic year.

column9: Good Friday - A day of mourning for Christians, commemorating the crucifixion of Jesus Christ.
column13: Children's Day - Celebrated on 14th November every year to honor the memory of India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, who was fondly called 'Chacha Nehru' (Uncle Nehru) by children.
column17: Science Exhibition - An event that showcases the scientific talent of the students. They display their scientific models, projects, and experiments.

column9: Easter Sunday - A celebration of the resurrection of Jesus Christ, three days after his crucifixion.

column17: Arts Festival - A festival that celebrates the artistic talent of the students. Students showcase their creativity through various art forms like painting, drawing, sculpture, etc.
column21: Terminal Exams: Terminal exams are conducted at the end of a term or a semester. They cover the entire syllabus taught in that particular term or semester.

column9: May Day - A day to honor the contributions of workers and laborers around the world.
column13: Women's Day - Celebrated on 8th March every year to celebrate the social, economic, cultural, and political achievements of women and to raise awareness about gender equality.
column17: Literary Fest - An event that promotes the literary talents of the students. It includes various competitions like debates, elocution, essay writing, etc.
column21: Pre-Board Exams: Pre-board exams are conducted before the actual board exams. They are conducted to prepare the students for the board exams and to assess their performance.

column9: Independence Day - A day to celebrate India's independence from British colonial rule in 1947.
column13: International Yoga Day - Celebrated on 21st June every year to promote yoga as a holistic approach to health and well-being.
column17: Cultural Fest - A celebration of the cultural diversity of the school. Students showcase their culture and traditions through various performances.
column21: Board Exams: Board exams are the most important exams in a student's academic life. They are conducted by the respective education board of a country and are usually conducted at the end of the academic year.

column9: Raksha Bandhan - A Hindu festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters.
column13: Ambedkar Jayanti - Celebrated on 14th April every year to mark the birth anniversary of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, who was a social reformer, jurist, and the architect of the Indian Constitution.
column17: Children's Day - A day dedicated to children, celebrated on the birth anniversary of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
column21: Entrance Exams: Entrance exams are conducted to select students for admission into various courses or colleges. They usually cover topics like aptitude, reasoning, and subject knowledge.

column9: Gandhi Jayanti - A day to honor the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi, a leader of India's independence movement and an advocate of non-violent civil disobedience.
column13: Martyr's Day - Observed on 30th January every year to pay tribute to Mahatma Gandhi, who was assassinated on this day in 1948.
column17: Teacher's Day - A day dedicated to teachers, celebrated on the birth anniversary of Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan.
column21: Scholarship Exams: Scholarship exams are conducted to award scholarships to deserving students. These exams are usually conducted by various organizations and educational institutions.

column9: Dussehra - A festival celebrating the victory of good over evil, symbolized by the triumph of Lord Rama over the demon king Ravana.
column13: Earth Day - Celebrated on 22nd April every year to raise awareness about environmental issues and to encourage people to take action to protect the planet.
column17: Gandhi Jayanti - Celebrated on the birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, this day promotes his teachings and principles.
column21: Olympiad Exams: Olympiad exams are conducted to assess the knowledge of students in various subjects like mathematics, science, and English. These exams are conducted at the national and international level.

column9: Diwali - A festival of lights, symbolizing the triumph of light over darkness, and the victory of good over evil.
column17: Independence Day - A national holiday celebrated on August 15th to commemorate India's independence from British rule.
column21: Aptitude Tests: Aptitude tests are conducted to assess the natural ability of a student in various areas like reasoning, numerical ability, and abstract reasoning.

column9: Christmas Day - A Christian holiday celebrating the birth of Jesus Christ.
column17: Republic Day - A national holiday celebrated on January 26th to commemorate the adoption of the Constitution of India.
column21: Language Proficiency Tests: Language proficiency tests are conducted to assess the proficiency of a student in a particular language.
